prompt: IMF's Special Drawing Right basket includes?
answers: USD, Euro, Yuan, Yen, Pound Sterling
explanation: SDR basket: US Dollar, Euro, Chinese Renminbi, Japanese Yen, British Pound Sterling. Weights reviewed every 5 years.
IMF quota determines member's subscription, voting power, and access to financing. India has increased quota over time.
World Bank Group: IBRD, IDA, IFC, MIGA, ICSID. IBRD and IDA provide loans; IFC private sector; MIGA guarantees; ICSID dispute settlement.
IDA provides concessional loans and grants to poorest countries. Soft loan arm of World Bank.

answers: Private sector investment - equity and debt
explanation: IFC (International Finance Corporation) invests in private sector projects in developing countries.

prompt: Asian Development Bank was established in?
explanation: ADB was established in 1966. Headquarters in Manila. Japan and USA are largest shareholders.

prompt: New Development Bank headquarters is in?
explanation: NDB (BRICS Bank) headquarters is in Shanghai, China. India has a regional office in Gujarat.
AIIB (Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank) was established in 2015. China is largest shareholder; India is second largest.
India has been among the largest borrowers from World Bank. India also borrows from ADB, AIIB.
BIS (Bank for International Settlements) is in Basel, Switzerland. It is the bank for central banks.

answers: Central banks and regulators from multiple countries
explanation: Basel Committee has members from nearly 30 jurisdictions including India. It sets global banking standards.
Basel I (1988) introduced minimum 8% capital for credit risk. Simple risk weights.

answers: Operational risk, market risk, three pillars
explanation: Basel II added operational risk, refined credit risk (internal models), and introduced three pillars including disclosure.
Basel III was developed post-2008 crisis to strengthen bank capital, liquidity, and leverage.

prompt: LCR requires banks to hold HQLA for?
explanation: LCR = High Quality Liquid Assets / Net cash outflows over 30 days. Must be at least 100%.
HQLA: Level 1 (cash, G-Secs - 100% value), Level 2A (sovereign, certain bonds - 85%), Level 2B (limited - 50%).

answers: Available stable funding to required stable funding
explanation: NSFR = Available Stable Funding / Required Stable Funding. Must be at least 100%. Ensures long-term stability.
G-SIFIs are banks whose failure could impact global financial system. They face higher capital requirements.
FATF recommendations are international standards. Countries implement through domestic laws. Grey/black list has reputational impact.

prompt: Financial Action Task Force was established in?
explanation: FATF was established in 1989 by G7 to combat money laundering. Now covers terror financing, proliferation financing.

answers: Finalization of Basel III - revised standards
explanation: Basel IV is not official name. It refers to finalization of Basel III (final reforms) - revised risk-weighted assets, output floor, etc.

answers: Banks using internal models cannot have capital less than 72.5% of standardized approach
explanation: Output floor limits benefit from internal models. Capital cannot be lower than 72.5% of what standardized approach would require.
India has implemented Basel III. RBI issued guidelines and banks have met the requirements. Basel III reforms (output floor) being phased.

explanation: PCA framework: when banks breach capital, NPA, profitability norms - restrictions on dividend, branch expansion, lending, etc.
RBI uses on-site inspection (annual financial inspection) and off-site surveillance (returns, CRILC, etc.) for supervision.
